paragraphs.name: b947
paragraphs.text: Ok, I get the even number thing, but seriously, why not 6, or 10?

paragraphs.name: bc0c
paragraphs.text: The majority of popular screen sizes are divisible by 8 which makes for an easy fit. Scaling by increments of 8 offers a good amount of options without overloading you with variables like a 6 point system, or limiting you like a 10 point system. Ultimately you have to decide what size is right for your audience. The “system” is only good if it is easy to follow and repeat.

paragraphs.name: 764c
paragraphs.text: In this comparison you can see an 8pt grid system vertically aligning the elements of a form versus a popular design system that utilizes arbitrary numbers to space and size elements.

paragraphs.name: 669b
paragraphs.text: The truth is none of them. They have different heights and paddings but without a system in place to clearly explain the thinking behind a style rule why should you follow it?

paragraphs.name: 764c
paragraphs.text: In this comparison you can see an 8pt grid system vertically aligning the elements of a form versus a popular design system that utilizes arbitrary numbers to space and size elements.

f9f97cac7725.title: I call it the “Bit Grid” or “Computational Grid” (8 bits 1 byte)

paragraphs.text: I call it the “Bit Grid” or “Computational Grid” (8 bits 1 byte)

Thanks for this great article. I have been using this system of design for over a year now and I love it. However, I do break away from the 8-pixel grid when it comes to fonts. With fonts I use a 4-pixel grid. That way, it still aligns great, but allows for a larger variety of sizes.

93caf3b34b1a.title: That image was based on Bootstrap.

paragraphs.name: b7fe
paragraphs.text: That image was based on Bootstrap. Foundation actually has a button height of 40.47px and an input height of 39px. That’s the kind of stuff I’m talking about.

4f748742ba83.title: 4 gives you too many options and more opportunities to disrupt the rhythm.

paragraphs.name: 1af0
paragraphs.text: 4 gives you too many options and more opportunities to disrupt the rhythm. You ultimately have to decide what scale works for your project but I’ve found 8 to be a good sweet spot. I found this article after I posted this, Nathan perfectly depicts why https://medium.com/eightshapes-llc/space-in-design-systems-188bcbae0d62#.tgpemkmya

b9823923d360.title: So the column grid is different and that still remains.

paragraphs.name: 9a4f
paragraphs.text: So the column grid is different and that still remains. The 8pt grid is an element grid so it defines the sizing and spacing of objects inside of that column. You are correct that in a responsive design your columns will be fluid and you can’t rely on them to be divisible by 8.

65c74bfc337f.title: This is something I am still exploring for my products.

paragraphs.name: e0d6
paragraphs.text: This is something I am still exploring for my products. I plan to make a more complete post about this exact topic. Bryn states in his article that he follows the 8pt grid for the UI and a 4pt baseline grid. This is what Google Material suggests too. It’s a good starting point to play with but it may not be right for all situations, stay tuned.

55f1da568aec.title: Yes. This is a very hard thing to describe without a solid example so I was nervous to include this…

paragraphs.name: ff57
paragraphs.text: Yes. This is a very hard thing to describe without a solid example so I was nervous to include this in the post. I plan to go deeper into this in another post. Sometimes it is appropriate when spacing icons, text, smaller elements to drop to 4pts. However, you do not want to open the door to increments like 12 and 20 because the system loses it’s simplicity.
